actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on April 10, 2024.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Schneider moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
The House observed a moment of silence in remembrance of the victims of the recent stabbing in Rockford, Illinois.

Mr. Pfluger asked unanimous consent That, it may be in order at any time on Thursday, April 11, 2024, for the Speaker to declare a recess, subject to the call of the Chair, for the purpose of receiving in joint meeting His Excellency Fumio Kishida, Prime Minister of Japan. Agreed to without objection.

Mr. Pfluger asked unanimous consent that he may hereafter be considered as the first sponsor of H.R. 4006, a bill originally introduced by Representative Johnson (OH), for the purpose of adding cosponsors and requesting reprintings pursuant to clause 7 of rule XII. Agreed to without objection.
On approving the Journal Agreed to by voice vote.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 406
actions-list.actionItem: 0 (Roll no. 106).
Considered as unfinished business. S. 2051 — "To reauthorize the Missing Children's Assistance Act, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 378
actions-list.actionItem: 26 (Roll no. 105).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 6655 — "To amend and reauthorize the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act."
The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on motions to suspend the rules, which had been debated and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of April 9.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 6:30 P.M. today.

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 2051.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Ms. Foxx moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. S. 2051 — "To reauthorize the Missing Children's Assistance Act, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6655.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Ms. Foxx moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6655 — "To amend and reauthorize the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6233.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 6233 — "To amend the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to authorize partnerships between States and nongovernmental entities for the purpose of reclaiming and restoring land and water resources adversely affected by coal mining activities before August 3, 1977, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6492.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Westerman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6492 — "To improve recreation opportunities on, and facilitate greater access to, Federal public land, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1829.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Ms. Hageman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1829 — "To require the Secretary of Agriculture to convey the Pleasant Valley Ranger District Administrative Site to Gila County, Arizona."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3250.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Ms. Hageman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 3250 — "To recognize the Margaret Woodbury Strong Museum in Rochester, New York."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1792.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Ms. Hageman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1792 — "To amend the South Pacific Tuna Act of 1988, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the chair put the question on the motion to suspend the rules. Ms. Hageman objected to the vote on the grounds that a quorum was not present. Further proceedings on the motion were postponed. The point of no quorum was considered as withdrawn.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 382.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Ms. Hageman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 382 — "To take certain land in the State of Washington into trust for the benefit of the Puyallup Tribe of the Puyallup Reservation, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6443.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Ms. Hageman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 6443 — "To take certain land in the State of California into trust for the benefit of the Jamul Indian Village of California Tribe, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1246.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Ms. Hageman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1246 — "To authorize leases of up to 99 years for land held in trust for federally recognized Indian Tribes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4389.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Ms. Hageman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 4389 — "To amend the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act to make improvements to that Act, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the chair put the question on the motion to suspend the rules. Ms. Hageman objected to the vote on the grounds that a quorum was not present. Further proceedings on the motion were postponed. The point of no quorum was considered as withdrawn.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6011.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Ms. Hageman moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6011 — "To direct the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to notify applicants of the completion status of right-of-way applications under section 501 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and section 28 of the Mineral Leasing Act."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of April 9.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the national emergency declared with respect to specified harmful foreign activities of the Government of the Russian Federation is to continue in effect beyond April 15, 2024.
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-130).

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the national emergency declared with respect to Somalia is to continue in effect beyond April 12, 2024.
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-129).
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mrs. Radewagen to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.

The Chair announced that he had examined the Journal of the last day's proceedings and had approved it. Mrs. Miller-Meeks demanded that the question be put on agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mrs. Miller-Meeks objected to the voice vote based upon the absence of a quorum and the Chair postponed further proceedings on the question of agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal until a time to be announced.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of April 9.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mike Ezell to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
